metadata.title: Tableau Calculation Functions Reference
metadata.description: Complete reference of all Tableau calculation functions, organized by category. For use with AI assistants to generate and validate Tableau calculated fields.

number_functions.description: Functions that perform mathematical operations on numeric values.

functions.name: ABS
functions.definition: Returns the absolute value of the given number.
functions.notes: See also SIGN.

functions.name: ACOS
functions.definition: Returns the arccosine (angle) of the given number.
functions.notes: Inverse of COS.

functions.name: ASIN
functions.definition: Returns the arcsine (angle) of a given number.
functions.notes: Inverse of SIN.

functions.name: ATAN
functions.definition: Returns the arctangent (angle) of a given number.
functions.notes: Inverse of TAN.

functions.name: ATAN2
functions.definition: Returns the arctangent (angle) between two numbers (x and y). The result is in radians.
functions.notes: See also ATAN, TAN, COT.

functions.name: CEILING
functions.definition: Rounds a number to the nearest integer of equal or greater value.
functions.notes: See also FLOOR and ROUND.

functions.name: COS
functions.definition: Returns the cosine of an angle. The number argument is the angle in radians.
functions.notes: Inverse of ACOS.

functions.name: COT
functions.definition: Returns the cotangent of an angle. The number argument is the angle in radians.
functions.notes: See also ATAN, TAN, PI. Use RADIANS to convert degrees to radians.

functions.name: DEGREES
functions.definition: Converts an angle in radians to degrees.
functions.notes: Inverse of RADIANS.

functions.name: DIV
functions.definition: Returns the integer part of a division operation where integer1 is divided by integer2.

functions.name: EXP
functions.definition: Returns e raised to the power of the given number.
functions.notes: See also LN.

functions.name: FLOOR
functions.definition: Rounds a number to the nearest integer of equal or lesser value.
functions.notes: See also CEILING and ROUND.

functions.name: HEXBINX
functions.definition: Maps an x,y coordinate to the x-coordinate of the nearest hexagonal bin. Bins have side length 1.
functions.notes: Used for hexagonal bin visualizations on maps. See also HEXBINY.

functions.name: HEXBINY
functions.definition: Maps an x,y coordinate to the y-coordinate of the nearest hexagonal bin. Bins have side length 1.
functions.notes: See also HEXBINX.

functions.name: LN
functions.definition: Returns the natural logarithm of a number.
functions.notes: See also EXP and LOG.

functions.name: LOG
functions.definition: Returns the logarithm of a number for the given base. If base is omitted, base 10 is used.
functions.notes: See also POWER, LN.

functions.name: MAX
functions.output: Same data type as argument, or NULL if any part is null
functions.definition: Returns the maximum of the two arguments, which must be of the same data type.
functions.notes: Can be used as both a number function and aggregate function.

functions.name: MIN
functions.output: Same data type as argument, or NULL if any part is null
functions.definition: Returns the minimum of the two arguments, which must be of the same data type.
functions.notes: Can be used as both a number function and aggregate function.

functions.name: PI
functions.definition: Returns the numeric constant pi: 3.14159...
functions.notes: Useful for trig functions that take input in radians.

functions.name: POWER
functions.definition: Raises the number to the specified power.
functions.notes: You can also use the ^ symbol: 5^3 = POWER(5,3) = 125

functions.name: RADIANS
functions.definition: Converts the given number from degrees to radians.
functions.notes: Inverse of DEGREES.

functions.name: ROUND
functions.definition: Rounds a number to the specified number of decimal places. If decimals is omitted, rounds to nearest integer.
functions.notes: Some databases allow negative decimals: -1 rounds to 10s, -2 rounds to 100s.

functions.name: SIGN
functions.definition: Returns the sign of a number: -1 if negative, 0 if zero, 1 if positive.
functions.notes: See also ABS.

functions.name: SIN
functions.definition: Returns the sine of an angle. The number argument is the angle in radians.
functions.notes: Inverse of ASIN.

functions.name: SQRT
functions.definition: Returns the square root of a number.
functions.notes: See also SQUARE.

functions.name: SQUARE
functions.definition: Returns the square of a number.
functions.notes: See also SQRT and POWER.

functions.name: TAN
functions.definition: Returns the tangent of an angle. The number argument is the angle in radians.
functions.notes: See also ATAN, ATAN2, COT, PI. Use RADIANS to convert degrees.

functions.name: ZN
functions.definition: Returns the expression if it is not null, otherwise returns zero. Use to replace null values with zeros.
functions.notes: Very useful when fields may contain nulls in a calculation.

functions.name: ASCII
functions.definition: Returns the ASCII code for the first character of a string.
functions.notes: Inverse of CHAR.

functions.name: CHAR
functions.definition: Returns the character encoded by the ASCII code number.
functions.notes: Inverse of ASCII.

functions.name: CONTAINS
functions.definition: Returns true if the given string contains the specified substring.
functions.notes: May be case-sensitive depending on data source.

functions.name: ENDSWITH
functions.definition: Returns true if the given string ends with the specified substring. Trailing white spaces are ignored.

functions.name: FIND
functions.definition: Returns the index position of substring in string, or 0 if not found. First character is position 1. Optional start argument specifies position to begin search.

functions.name: FINDNTH
functions.definition: Returns the position of the nth occurrence of substring within the specified string.

functions.name: LEFT
functions.definition: Returns the left-most n characters in the string.
functions.notes: See also MID and RIGHT.

functions.name: LEN
functions.definition: Returns the length of the string.
functions.notes: Not to be confused with the spatial function LENGTH.

functions.name: LOWER
functions.definition: Returns the provided string in all lowercase characters.
functions.notes: See also UPPER and PROPER.

functions.name: LTRIM
functions.definition: Returns the provided string with any leading spaces removed.
functions.notes: See also RTRIM.

functions.name: MID
functions.definition: Returns a string starting at the specified index position. Optional length argument limits the number of characters returned.
functions.notes: See also LEFT and RIGHT.

functions.name: PROPER
functions.definition: Returns the string with the first letter of each word capitalized and remaining letters in lowercase.
functions.notes: Spaces and non-alphanumeric characters like punctuation are treated as separators. Only available for some flat files and in extracts.

functions.name: REPLACE
functions.definition: Searches string for substring and replaces it with replacement. If substring is not found, the string is unchanged.
functions.notes: See also REGEXP_REPLACE.

functions.name: RIGHT
functions.definition: Returns the right-most n characters in the string.
functions.notes: See also LEFT and MID.

functions.name: RTRIM
functions.definition: Returns the provided string with any trailing spaces removed.
functions.notes: See also LTRIM and TRIM.

functions.name: SPACE
functions.definition: Returns a string composed of the specified number of repeated spaces.

functions.name: SPLIT
functions.definition: Returns a substring from a string, using a delimiter character to divide the string into tokens. Positive token_number counts from start; negative counts from end.
functions.notes: Available for: Tableau extracts, Excel, Text, Salesforce, OData, Vertica, Oracle, MySQL, PostgreSQL, Teradata, Redshift, SQL Server, and others.

functions.name: STARTSWITH
functions.definition: Returns true if string starts with substring. Leading white spaces are ignored.
functions.notes: See also CONTAINS.

functions.name: TRIM
functions.definition: Returns the provided string with leading and trailing spaces removed.
functions.notes: See also LTRIM and RTRIM.

functions.name: UPPER
functions.definition: Returns the provided string in all uppercase characters.
functions.notes: See also PROPER and LOWER.

date_functions.description: Functions that create, transform, or extract parts of date and datetime values. Note: Date functions do not account for configured fiscal year start.

date_part_values.description: Valid values for the date_part argument used in many date functions.

values.description: Day of the year; Jan 1 is 1, Feb 1 is 32, etc.
1–52, start of week is always Monday
1–7, start of week is always Monday

functions.name: DATE
functions.definition: Returns a date given a number, string, or date expression. Type conversion function.

functions.name: DATEADD
functions.definition: Returns the date with the specified number interval added to the specified date_part of that date.
functions.example:
DATEADD('week', 1, [due date])  -- push due dates by one week
DATEADD('day', 280, #2/20/21#) = #November 27, 2021#
functions.notes: Supports ISO 8601 dates.

functions.name: DATEDIFF
functions.definition: Returns the difference between date1 and date2 expressed in units of date_part.
functions.example:
DATEDIFF('day', #3/25/1986#, #2/20/2021#) = 12751
DATEDIFF('month', [date joined band], [date left band])
functions.notes: Supports ISO 8601 dates.

functions.name: DATENAME
functions.definition: Returns date_part of date as a string.
functions.notes: Supports ISO 8601. Similar to DATEPART but returns string. Inverse of DATEPARSE.

functions.name: DATEPARSE
functions.definition: Returns a specifically formatted string as a date. The date_format argument must match the date_string exactly.
functions.notes: Database limitations apply. Inverse functions are DATENAME and DATEPART.

functions.name: DATEPART
functions.definition: Returns date_part of date as an integer.
functions.notes: Supports ISO 8601. Similar to DATENAME but returns integer.

functions.name: DATETRUNC
functions.definition: Truncates the date to the accuracy specified by date_part. Returns a new date at the start of the specified period.
functions.notes: Supports ISO 8601 dates.

functions.name: DAY
functions.definition: Returns the day of the given date as an integer (1–31).
functions.notes: See also WEEK, MONTH, QUARTER, YEAR, and ISO equivalents.

functions.name: ISDATE
functions.definition: Returns true if a given string is a valid date. Input must be a string type.
functions.notes: Cannot be used for a field with a date data type—will return an error.

functions.name: ISOQUARTER
functions.definition: Returns the ISO8601 week-based quarter of a given date as an integer.
functions.notes: See also ISOWEEK, ISOWEEKDAY, ISOYEAR.

functions.name: ISOWEEK
functions.definition: Returns the ISO8601 week-based week of a given date as an integer.
functions.notes: See also ISOWEEKDAY, ISOQUARTER, ISOYEAR.

functions.name: ISOWEEKDAY
functions.definition: Returns the ISO8601 week-based weekday of a given date as an integer.
functions.notes: See also ISOWEEK, ISOQUARTER, ISOYEAR.

functions.name: ISOYEAR
functions.definition: Returns the ISO8601 week-based year of a given date as an integer.
functions.notes: See also ISOWEEK, ISOWEEKDAY, ISOQUARTER.

functions.name: MAKEDATE
functions.definition: Returns a date value constructed from the specified year, month, and day.
functions.notes: Available for Tableau Data Extracts. Check availability for other data sources.

functions.name: MAKEDATETIME
functions.definition: Returns a datetime that combines a date and a time. The date can be a date, datetime, or string type. The time must be a datetime.
functions.notes: Available only for MySQL-compatible connections (MySQL and Amazon Aurora).

functions.name: MAKETIME
functions.definition: Returns a date value constructed from the specified hour, minute, and second.
functions.notes: Because Tableau does not support a time data type, output is a datetime. The date portion will be 1/1/1899.

functions.name: MAX
functions.output: Same data type as argument, or NULL
functions.definition: Returns the maximum of two date arguments.
functions.notes: Also works as an aggregate function.

functions.name: MIN
functions.output: Same data type as argument, or NULL
functions.definition: Returns the minimum of two date arguments.
functions.notes: Also works as an aggregate function.

functions.name: MONTH
functions.definition: Returns the month of the given date as an integer (1–12).
functions.notes: See also DAY, WEEK, QUARTER, YEAR, and ISO equivalents.

functions.name: NOW
functions.definition: Returns the current local system date and time.
functions.notes: For live connections, system time may be in another timezone. See also TODAY.

functions.name: QUARTER
functions.definition: Returns the quarter of the given date as an integer (1–4).
functions.notes: See also DAY, WEEK, MONTH, YEAR, and ISO equivalents.

functions.name: TODAY
functions.definition: Returns the current local system date.
functions.notes: Similar to NOW but returns Date instead of Datetime.

functions.name: WEEK
functions.definition: Returns the week of the given date as an integer (1–52).
functions.notes: See also DAY, MONTH, QUARTER, YEAR, and ISO equivalents.

functions.name: YEAR
functions.definition: Returns the year of the given date as an integer.
functions.notes: See also DAY, WEEK, MONTH, QUARTER, and ISO equivalents.

logical_functions.description: Functions that test expressions and return boolean values or conditional results.

functions.name: AND
functions.definition: Performs a logical conjunction on two expressions. Returns true only if both sides are true.
functions.notes: Often used with IF and IIF. See also NOT and OR.

functions.name: CASE
functions.syntax: CASE expression WHEN value1 THEN result1 [WHEN value2 THEN result2 ...] [ELSE default] END
functions.output: Depends on data type of THEN values
functions.definition: Evaluates the expression and compares it to a series of values. Returns the result for the first matching value.
functions.example: CASE [Season] WHEN 'Summer' THEN 'Sandals' WHEN 'Winter' THEN 'Boots' ELSE 'Sneakers' END
functions.notes: Used with WHEN, THEN, ELSE, and END.

functions.name: ELSE
functions.definition: Optional part of IF or CASE expression. Specifies a default value to return if none of the tested expressions are true.
functions.notes: Used with CASE, WHEN, IF, ELSEIF, THEN, and END.

functions.name: ELSEIF
functions.definition: Optional part of an IF expression used to specify additional conditions beyond the initial IF.
functions.notes: Used with IF, THEN, ELSE, and END.

functions.name: END
functions.definition: Used to close an IF or CASE expression.

functions.name: IF
functions.syntax: IF condition THEN result [ELSEIF condition2 THEN result2 ...] [ELSE default] END
functions.output: Depends on data type of THEN values
functions.definition: Tests a series of expressions and returns the value of the THEN expression for the first true condition.
functions.example: IF [Season] = "Summer" THEN 'Sandals' ELSEIF [Season] = "Winter" THEN 'Boots' ELSE 'Sneakers' END

functions.name: IFNULL
functions.output: Depends on data type of expr values
functions.definition: Returns expr1 if it is not null, otherwise returns expr2.
functions.notes: Compare with ISNULL. See also ZN.

functions.name: IIF
functions.output: Depends on data type of values
functions.definition: Checks whether a condition is met. Returns then if test is true, else if false, and optional unknown if test is null.
functions.notes: Evaluation stops as soon as a true condition is found.

functions.name: IN
functions.definition: Returns TRUE if any value in expr1 matches any value in expr2.
functions.notes: See also WHEN.

functions.name: ISDATE
functions.definition: Returns true if a string is a valid date. The input expression must be a string field.
functions.notes: What counts as a valid date depends on the system locale.

functions.name: ISNULL
functions.definition: Returns true if the expression is null.
functions.notes: Compare with IFNULL. See also ZN.

functions.name: MAX
functions.definition: Returns the maximum of two arguments as a logical comparison.

functions.name: MIN
functions.definition: Returns the minimum of two arguments as a logical comparison.

functions.name: NOT
functions.definition: Performs logical negation on an expression.

functions.name: OR
functions.definition: Performs a logical disjunction on two expressions. Returns true if either side is true.
functions.notes: Often used with IF and IIF. See also AND and NOT.

functions.name: THEN
functions.definition: Required part of an IF, ELSEIF, or CASE expression. Defines the result to return when a specific condition is true.

functions.name: WHEN
functions.definition: Required part of a CASE expression. Finds the first value that matches the CASE expression and returns the corresponding THEN result.
functions.notes: Used with CASE, THEN, ELSE, and END.

functions.name: ZN
functions.definition: Returns the expression if it is not null, otherwise returns zero.
functions.notes: See also ISNULL.

aggregate_functions.description: Functions that compute a single value from a group of values. Aggregate functions can only be used with measures or in calculated fields.

functions.name: ATTR
functions.definition: Returns the value of the expression if it has a single value for all rows. Otherwise returns an asterisk. Null values are ignored.

functions.name: AVG
functions.definition: Returns the average of all the values in the expression. Null values are ignored.
functions.notes: Can only be used with numeric fields.

functions.name: COLLECT
functions.definition: An aggregate calculation that combines the values in the argument field. Null values are ignored.
functions.notes: Can only be used with spatial fields.

functions.name: CORR
functions.definition: Returns the Pearson correlation coefficient of two expressions. Measures linear relationship between two variables.
functions.notes: Results: 1 = exact positive linear relationship, 0 = no relationship, -1 = exact negative relationship. Square of CORR equals R-Squared of linear trend line.

functions.name: COUNT
functions.definition: Returns the number of items in a group. Null values are not counted.

functions.name: COUNTD
functions.definition: Returns the number of distinct items in a group. Null values are not counted.

functions.name: COVAR
functions.definition: Returns the sample covariance of two expressions. Uses n-1 to normalize.
functions.notes: Appropriate when data is a random sample. See also COVARP.

functions.name: COVARP
functions.definition: Returns the population covariance of two expressions. Uses n to normalize.
functions.notes: Appropriate when data covers the entire population. See also COVAR.

functions.name: MAX
functions.definition: Returns the maximum value across all records in the expression.

functions.name: MEDIAN
functions.definition: Returns the median of an expression across all records. Null values are ignored.
functions.notes: Can only be used with numeric fields. Limited database support; consider using an extract.

functions.name: MIN
functions.definition: Returns the minimum value across all records in the expression.

functions.name: PERCENTILE
functions.definition: Returns the percentile value from the given expression corresponding to the specified number (must be between 0 and 1).
functions.notes: Available for: Excel/Text (non-legacy), Extracts, Sybase IQ 15.1+, Oracle 10+, Cloudera Hive, Hortonworks Hive, EXASolution 4.2+.

functions.name: STDEV
functions.definition: Returns the statistical standard deviation of all values based on a sample of the population.

functions.name: STDEVP
functions.definition: Returns the statistical standard deviation of all values based on a biased (full) population.

functions.name: SUM
functions.definition: Returns the sum of all values in the expression. Null values are ignored.
functions.notes: Can only be used with numeric fields.

functions.name: VAR
functions.definition: Returns the statistical variance of all values based on a sample of the population.

functions.name: VARP
functions.definition: Returns the statistical variance of all values on the entire population.

user_functions.description: Functions that return information about the currently signed-in Tableau user. Useful for row-level security and personalized views.

functions.name: FULLNAME
functions.definition: Returns the full name for the current signed-in user.
functions.example:
FULLNAME() -- returns "Hamlin Myrer"
[Manager] = FULLNAME()  -- filter by manager name
functions.notes: Checks Tableau Server/Cloud user profile when published.

functions.name: ISFULLNAME
functions.definition: Returns TRUE if the current user's full name matches the specified string.

functions.name: ISMEMBEROF
functions.definition: Returns TRUE if the currently signed-in user is a member of the specified group.
functions.notes: Returns TRUE if group name is "All Users". Group membership changes take effect in new sessions.

functions.name: ISUSERNAME
functions.definition: Returns TRUE if the current user's username matches the specified username.

functions.name: USERDOMAIN
functions.definition: Returns the domain for the current signed-in user.
functions.notes: Returns null when Tableau Desktop is used and the user is not connected to a server.

functions.name: USERNAME
functions.definition: Returns the username for the current signed-in user.
functions.example:
USERNAME() -- returns "hmyrer"
[Author] = USERNAME()  -- filter by current user
functions.notes: Checks Tableau Server/Cloud login when published.

functions.name: USERATTRIBUTE
functions.definition: Returns the value of the named attribute for the current user, as set in the identity provider.
functions.notes: Available for Tableau Cloud with connected IdP.

functions.name: USERATTRIBUTEINCLUDES
functions.definition: Returns TRUE if the specified attribute for the current user includes the given value.
functions.notes: Available for Tableau Cloud with connected IdP.

table_calculation_functions.description: Functions that perform computations on values in the current view table/partition, rather than on the underlying data. Computed after aggregation.

functions.name: FIRST
functions.definition: Returns the number of rows from the current row to the first row in the partition. Negative when current row is after the first row.
functions.example: FIRST() = -2  -- when current row index is 3

functions.name: INDEX
functions.definition: Returns the index of the current row in the partition, without any sorting with regard to value. First row index starts at 1.
functions.example: INDEX() = 3  -- for the third row in the partition

functions.name: LAST
functions.definition: Returns the number of rows from the current row to the last row in the partition. Positive when current row is before the last row.
functions.example: LAST() = 4  -- when current row index is 3 of 7

functions.name: LOOKUP
functions.definition: Returns the value of the expression in a target row specified as a relative offset from the current row. Returns NULL if target row cannot be determined.
functions.example:
LOOKUP(SUM([Profit]), FIRST()+2)  -- SUM(Profit) in the third row
LOOKUP(SUM([Sales]), 2)  -- sales from 2 rows ahead
functions.notes: Use FIRST()+n and LAST()-n for offsets relative to first/last rows. If offset is omitted, can be set on the field menu.

functions.name: PREVIOUS_VALUE
functions.definition: Returns the value of this calculation in the previous row. Returns the given expression if the current row is the first row of the partition.
functions.example: SUM([Profit]) * PREVIOUS_VALUE(1)  -- running product of SUM(Profit)

functions.name: RANK
functions.definition: Returns the standard competition rank for the current row in the partition. Identical values receive the same rank, creating gaps in the sequence. Default order is descending.
functions.notes: Nulls are ignored and not counted. See also RANK_DENSE, RANK_MODIFIED, RANK_PERCENTILE, RANK_UNIQUE.

functions.name: RANK_DENSE
functions.definition: Returns the dense rank for the current row. Identical values receive the same rank with no gaps in the sequence. Default order is descending.
functions.notes: Nulls are ignored. No gaps in ranking sequence.

functions.name: RANK_MODIFIED
functions.definition: Returns the modified competition rank. Identical values receive the same rank (the last in that group's sequence). Default order is descending.
functions.notes: Nulls are ignored.

functions.name: RANK_PERCENTILE
functions.definition: Returns the percentile rank for the current row in the partition. Default order is ascending.
functions.notes: Nulls are ignored and do not count against total records in percentile calculations.

functions.name: RANK_UNIQUE
functions.definition: Returns the unique rank for the current row. Identical values receive different ranks. Default order is descending.
functions.notes: Nulls are ignored. Every row receives a unique rank.

functions.name: RUNNING_AVG
functions.definition: Returns the running average of the given expression, from the first row in the partition to the current row.

functions.name: RUNNING_COUNT
functions.definition: Returns the running count of the given expression, from the first row in the partition to the current row.

functions.name: RUNNING_MAX
functions.definition: Returns the running maximum of the given expression, from the first row in the partition to the current row.

functions.name: RUNNING_MIN
functions.definition: Returns the running minimum of the given expression, from the first row in the partition to the current row.

functions.name: RUNNING_SUM
functions.definition: Returns the running sum of the given expression, from the first row in the partition to the current row.

functions.name: SIZE
functions.definition: Returns the number of rows in the partition.

functions.name: TOTAL
functions.definition: Returns the total for the given expression in a table calculation partition.
functions.example: TOTAL(SUM([Sales]))  -- total sales in the partition
functions.notes: Default Compute Using is Table (Across). Right-click to edit Table Calculation for different compute options.

functions.name: WINDOW_AVG
functions.definition: Returns the average of the expression within the window. Window is defined as offsets from current row. If start and end are omitted, entire partition is used.
functions.example: WINDOW_AVG(SUM([Profit]), -2, 0)  -- avg of last 2 rows to current
functions.notes: Use FIRST()+n and LAST()-n for relative offsets.

functions.name: WINDOW_CORR
functions.definition: Returns the Pearson correlation coefficient of two expressions within the window.
functions.notes: Use FIRST()+n and LAST()-n for relative offsets.

functions.name: WINDOW_COUNT
functions.definition: Returns the count of the expression within the window.

functions.name: WINDOW_COVAR
functions.definition: Returns the sample covariance of two expressions within the window. Uses n-1 normalization.

functions.name: WINDOW_COVARP
functions.definition: Returns the population covariance of two expressions within the window. Uses n normalization.

functions.name: WINDOW_MAX
functions.definition: Returns the maximum of the expression within the window.

functions.name: WINDOW_MEDIAN
functions.definition: Returns the median of the expression within the window.

functions.name: WINDOW_MIN
functions.definition: Returns the minimum of the expression within the window.

functions.name: WINDOW_PERCENTILE
functions.definition: Returns the value corresponding to the specified percentile (0–1) within the window.

functions.name: WINDOW_STDEV
functions.definition: Returns the sample standard deviation of the expression within the window.

functions.name: WINDOW_STDEVP
functions.definition: Returns the biased (population) standard deviation of the expression within the window.

functions.name: WINDOW_SUM
functions.definition: Returns the sum of the expression within the window.

functions.name: WINDOW_VAR
functions.definition: Returns the sample variance of the expression within the window.

functions.name: WINDOW_VARP
functions.definition: Returns the biased (population) variance of the expression within the window.

regex_functions.description: Regular expression functions for advanced string pattern matching and extraction. Availability depends on data source.

functions.name: REGEXP_MATCH
functions.definition: Returns true if the string contains a substring that matches the regular expression pattern.
functions.notes: Availability depends on data source.

functions.name: REGEXP_EXTRACT
functions.definition: Returns a substring of the string that matches the capturing group within the regular expression pattern.
functions.notes: Availability depends on data source.

functions.name: REGEXP_EXTRACT_NTH
functions.definition: Returns a substring of the string using the regular expression pattern. The substring is matched to the nth capturing group, where n is the index.
functions.notes: Availability depends on data source.

functions.name: REGEXP_REPLACE
functions.definition: Returns a copy of the string where the substring matching the regular expression pattern is replaced with replacement.
functions.notes: Availability depends on data source.

spatial_functions.description: Functions for working with geographic and spatial data. Require spatial data types.

functions.name: AREA
functions.definition: Returns the area of a spatial polygon in the specified units.
functions.notes: Valid units: 'meters', 'km', 'miles', 'feet'.

functions.name: BUFFER
functions.definition: Returns a polygon around a spatial point at the specified distance.

functions.name: DISTANCE
functions.definition: Returns the distance between two spatial points in the specified units.
functions.notes: Valid units: 'meters', 'km', 'miles', 'feet'.

functions.name: INTERSECTION
functions.definition: Returns a geometry representing the spatial intersection of two shapes.

functions.name: INTERSECTS
functions.definition: Returns true if two spatial objects intersect.

functions.name: LENGTH
functions.definition: Returns the length of a spatial line in the specified units.
functions.notes: Not to be confused with the string function LEN.

functions.name: MAKELINE
functions.definition: Creates a line mark between two spatial points.
functions.example: MAKELINE(MAKEPOINT([Origin Lat], [Origin Lon]), MAKEPOINT([Dest Lat], [Dest Lon]))

functions.name: MAKEPOINT
functions.definition: Converts data from latitude and longitude columns into spatial objects.
functions.notes: Latitude and Longitude must be in decimal degrees.

functions.name: OUTLINE
functions.definition: Returns a linestring geometry representing the outline of a polygon.

functions.name: SHAPETYPE
functions.definition: Returns the type of the geometry as a string.

functions.name: DIFFERENCE
functions.definition: Returns the geometric difference — the part of spatial1 that does not intersect with spatial2.

functions.name: SYMDIFFERENCE
functions.definition: Returns the symmetric difference — the parts of each geometry that do not overlap.

functions.name: VALIDATE
functions.definition: Returns true if the spatial object is geometrically valid.

analytics_extension_functions.description: Functions for passing data to external analytics services (TabPy, R, MATLAB). Require an Analytics Extension connection to be configured.

script_functions.description: Pass expressions directly to an external analytics service instance. Use .argN in R expressions and _argN in Python expressions.

functions.name: SCRIPT_BOOL
functions.definition: Returns a Boolean result from the specified expression passed to a running analytics extension service.
functions.example:
SCRIPT_BOOL("is.finite(.arg1)", SUM([Profit]))
SCRIPT_BOOL("return map(lambda x : x > 0, _arg1)", SUM([Profit]))
functions.notes: R uses .arg1, .arg2, etc. Python uses _arg1, _arg2, etc.

functions.name: SCRIPT_INT
functions.definition: Returns an integer result from the specified expression passed to a running analytics extension service.
functions.notes: R uses .arg1, .arg2, etc. Python uses _arg1, _arg2, etc.

functions.name: SCRIPT_REAL
functions.definition: Returns a real number result from the specified expression passed to a running analytics extension service.
functions.notes: R uses .arg1, .arg2, etc. Python uses _arg1, _arg2, etc.

functions.name: SCRIPT_STR
functions.definition: Returns a string result from the specified expression passed to a running analytics extension service.
functions.example:
SCRIPT_STR('gsub(".*_", "", .arg1)', ATTR([Store ID]))
SCRIPT_STR("return map(lambda x : x[:2], _arg1)", ATTR([Region]))
functions.notes: R uses .arg1, .arg2, etc. Python uses _arg1, _arg2, etc.

model_extension_functions.description: Use named models deployed on a TabPy external service.

functions.name: MODEL_EXTENSION_BOOL
functions.definition: Returns the boolean result of an expression as calculated by a named model deployed on a TabPy external service.
functions.notes: Data types and order of expressions must match input arguments of the deployed model.

functions.name: MODEL_EXTENSION_INT
functions.definition: Returns an integer result of an expression as calculated by a named model deployed on a TabPy external service.
functions.notes: Data types and order of expressions must match input arguments of the deployed model.

functions.name: MODEL_EXTENSION_REAL
functions.definition: Returns a real number result of an expression as calculated by a named model deployed on a TabPy external service.
functions.notes: Data types and order of expressions must match input arguments of the deployed model.

functions.name: MODEL_EXTENSION_STRING
functions.definition: Returns the string result of an expression as calculated by a named model deployed on a TabPy external service.
functions.notes: Data types and order of expressions must match input arguments of the deployed model.

predictive_modeling_functions.description: Native Tableau predictive modeling functions. No external connection required.

functions.name: MODEL_PERCENTILE
functions.definition: Returns the probability (between 0 and 1) that the expected value is less than or equal to the observed mark. This is the Posterior Predictive Distribution Function (CDF). Inverse of MODEL_QUANTILE.

functions.name: MODEL_QUANTILE
functions.definition: Returns a target numeric value at the specified quantile within the probable range. This is the Posterior Predictive Quantile. Inverse of MODEL_PERCENTILE.
functions.example: MODEL_QUANTILE(0.5, SUM([Sales]), COUNT([Orders]))  -- median predicted sales

rawsql_passthrough_functions.description: Functions for sending raw SQL expressions directly to the underlying database. Use when native Tableau functions are insufficient.

functions.name: RAWSQL_BOOL
functions.definition: Returns a Boolean result from the given SQL expression. Use %1, %2, etc. as placeholders for Tableau arguments.

functions.name: RAWSQL_DATE
functions.definition: Returns a Date result from the given SQL expression.

functions.name: RAWSQL_DATETIME
functions.definition: Returns a Datetime result from the given SQL expression.

functions.name: RAWSQL_INT
functions.definition: Returns an integer result from the given SQL expression.

functions.name: RAWSQL_REAL
functions.definition: Returns a real number result from the given SQL expression.

functions.name: RAWSQL_SPATIAL
functions.definition: Returns a spatial result from the given SQL expression.

functions.name: RAWSQL_STR
functions.definition: Returns a string result from the given SQL expression.

functions.name: RAWSQLAGG_BOOL
functions.definition: Returns an aggregated Boolean result from the given SQL expression.

functions.name: RAWSQLAGG_DATE
functions.definition: Returns an aggregated Date result from the given SQL expression.

functions.name: RAWSQLAGG_DATETIME
functions.definition: Returns an aggregated Datetime result from the given SQL expression.

functions.name: RAWSQLAGG_INT
functions.definition: Returns an aggregated integer result from the given SQL expression.

functions.name: RAWSQLAGG_REAL
functions.definition: Returns an aggregated real number result from the given SQL expression.

functions.name: RAWSQLAGG_STR
functions.definition: Returns an aggregated string result from the given SQL expression.
